Tuition: $7,900. Course Dates: July 02 - August 03.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: Hi...
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" program. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Conducted in Spanish. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 and S140. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Bilbao and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further details visit the program page on the Study Abroad website. Credits: 1. Tuition: See SPAN S130 & SPAN S140. Course Dates: May 28 - July 20.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: Hi...
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" program. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Conducted in Spanish. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 and S140. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Bilbao and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further details visit the program page on the Study Abroad website. Credits: 1. Tuition: See SPAN S130 & SPAN S140. Course Dates: May 28 - July 20.

subject: SUMR
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Not for credit. This course is part of the IVY program. This course examines the rich and varied musical traditions created by performers across the United States during the long twentieth century—from jazz, blues and country, to rock’n’roll and zydeco. This interdisciplinary course considers the major trends, influential artists, and disparate influences affecting American expressive culture through time. More broadly, vernacular music is used as a vehicle for understanding the intersections of tradition, ethnicity, technology, geography, culture and politics in the United States. In addition to highlighting musicians, the seminar contextualizes vernacular genres by mapping the cradles of American music—New Orleans, the Mississippi Delta, Memphis, the American Piedmont, etc—in addition to commercial hubs including New York, Detroit, Nashville, and Chicago. By the end of the course, students will have a working understanding of the people and places shaping American soundscapes and national culture. Enrollment limited to 15 students. Credit: 0. Tuition: $2,175. Session B: Jul 2 - August 3.

subject: SUMR
title: American Regionalism
description: Not for credit. This course is part of the IVY program. This course examines the phenomenon of regionalism in American culture by considering the history of “regionalism” and its depiction in American literature. How might a regionalist sensibility manifest itself in narrative? In what ways do varying geographies – of New England, the South, the West – register in cultural texts, and in what ways do their respective literatures differ from one another? What exactly is “local color,” and how is it presented – and preserved – textually? We will study the emergence of “regionalism” through texts from the height of the regionalist movement and will also consider whether regionalism can be considered a contemporary (or continuous) American literary phenomenon. Authors include Robert Frost, Mark Twain, William Faulkner, and Willa Cather. Enrollment limited to 15 students. Credit: 0. Tuition: $2,175. Session B: Jul 2 - August 3.

subject: SUMR
title: Writing for Cross-Cultural Und...
description: Not for credit. Designed primarily for students whose first language is not English, this noncredit course offers practice in academic writing for students who need additional preparation for rigorous college writing courses. Special attention is paid to the conventions and practices of American academic writing. Students review the basics of English grammar and syntax while learning strategies of analysis, argument, and source use. Readings include short scholarly essays and excerpts from challenging and provocative longer works. Writing assignments include several one-page response papers and three longer academic essays. Enrollment limited to 15 students. Credit: 0. Tuition $2,175. Session B: July 2 - August 3.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
description: Offered in Arusha, Tanzania. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Prerequisite: SWAH 120 (Beginning Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. For further details visit the program page on the Study Abroad website. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of SWAH S140). Tuition: $2,500. Course Dates: May 28 - July 20.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
description: Offered in Arusha, Tanzania. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Prerequisite: SWAH 120 (Beginning Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S130. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Arusha and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further details visit the program page on the Study Abroad website. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $2,500. Course Dates: May 28 - July 20.

subject: SWAH
title: Advanced Kiswahili
description: Offered in Arusha, Tanzania. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140 (Intermediate Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Arusha and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further details visit the program page on the Study Abroad website. Credits: 2. Tuition: $5,000. Course Dates: May 28 - July 20.

subject: THST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. An introduction to the theory and practice of scenic design for theater. Topics include the history of scenic design; visual storytelling and theatricality; text analysis; the relationship between the designer, the director and the text; the role of the designer within the production process; methods for communicating design concepts (such as rendering, modeling and drafting); and considerations for evaluating a given design. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,050. Session B: July 2 - August 3.

subject: THST
title: Theater Now
description: Study of drama, performance, and dance-theater created in the last ten years, with special attention to works produced in 2013 and 2014. Readings from both published and unpublished American and British plays, contemporary criticism, interviews, and essays by the artists themselves. Video of works created by companies such as Elevator Repair Service, Les Freres Corbusier, and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Will include attendance of productions in and around New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,050. Session B: July 2 - August 3.

subject: THST
title: Modern American Drama
description: Online Course. In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Technology fee: $85. Tuition $4,050. Session A: May 28 - June 29.

subject: THST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Theoretical and practical considerations for conceptual sound design, the creation of aural content and imagery in support of dramatic action. The use of sound to communicate meaning and intention effectively in a theatrical setting. Auditory culture and the phenomenology of hearing; the role of technology in sound design; development of critical listening skills and of a foundational vocabulary for the medium. Projects focus on the generation of content and ideas in support of a text. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,050. Session A: May 28 - June 29.

subject: WGSS
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to the Peabody Museum, the Yale Farm, and the Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,050. Session A: May 28 - June 29.

subject: WGSS
title: Women's Bodies: A Biosocial Ap...
description: Evolutionary and biosocial perspectives on female reproductive lives. Physiological, ecological, and social aspects of women's development from puberty through menopause and aging, with special attention to reproductive processes such as pregnancy, birth, and lactation. Variation in female life histories in a variety of cultural and ecological settings. Examples from both traditional and modern societies. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,050. Session A: May 28 - June 29.

subject: WGSS
title: Race and Gender in Asian Ameri...
long_title: Race and Gender in Asian American Popular Culture
description: Asian American popular culture thought through the shifting histories and ideologies that give it meaning. Considers the changing ideas of "Asian American" as a raced and gendered category that both represents and makes culture. Readings cover a variety of popular genres including film, television, music, and digital technologies. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,050. Session B: July 2 - August 3.

subject: WGSS
title: The Olympic Games: Ancient to...
long_title: The Olympic Games: Ancient to Modern
description: Introduction to the history of the Olympic Games from antiquity to the present. The mythology of athletic events in ancient Greece and the ritual, political, and social ramifications of the actual competitions. The revival of the modern Olympic movement in 1896, the political investment of the Greek state at the time, and specific games as they illustrate the convergence of athletic cultures and sociopolitical transformations in the twentieth century. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,050. Session A: May 28 - June 29.

subject: WGSS
title: Men, Manhood, and Masculinity
description: Cultural and historic constructions of masculinity explored through an investigation of male bodies, sexualities, and social interactions. Multiple masculinities; the relationship between hegemonic, nonhegemonic, and subordinate masculinities. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,050. Session B: July 2 - August 3.
